headline: California Roll Sushi
description: Make your own delicious California sushi rolls with seaweed sheets, sweet and tangy sushi rice, cucumber, avocado, and a creamy imitation crab filling.
name: California Roll Sushi
recipeIngredient: 2 avocados - pitted, peeled, and sliced the long way

recipeInstructions.text: Wash the rice in several changes of water until the rinse water is no longer cloudy, drain well, and place in a covered pan or rice cooker with 1 cup water. Bring to a boil, reduce heat to a simmer, and cover the pan. Allow the rice to simmer until the top looks dry, about 15 minutes. Turn off the heat, and let stand for 10 minutes to absorb the rest of the water.
Mix the rice vinegar and sugar in a small bowl until the sugar has dissolved, and stir the mixture into the cooked rice until well combined. Allow the rice to cool, and set aside.

Mix the imitation crabmeat with mayonnaise in a bowl, and set aside. To roll the sushi, cover a bamboo rolling mat with plastic wrap. Lay a sheet of nori, shiny side down, on the plastic wrap. With wet fingers, firmly pat a thin, even layer of prepared rice over the nori, leaving 1/4 inch uncovered at the bottom edge of the sheet. Sprinkle the rice with about 1/2 teaspoon of sesame seeds, and gently press them into the rice. Carefully flip the nori sheet over so the seaweed side is up.

Place 2 or 3 long cucumber spears, 2 or 3 slices of avocado, and about 1 tablespoon of imitation crab mixture in a line across the nori sheet, about 1/4 from the uncovered edge. Pick up the edge of the bamboo rolling sheet, fold the bottom edge of the sheet up, enclosing the filling, and tightly roll the sushi into a cylinder about 1 1/2 inch in diameter. Once the sushi is rolled, wrap it in the mat and gently squeeze to compact it tightly.
Cut each roll into 1 inch pieces with a very sharp knife dipped in water.

review.reviewBody: it was good and it was fun to make
Recipe called to cook rice in a pan , which burned all of the rice at the bottom, overall not amazing
So So SoSo AMAZING. HAVE TO TRY IT!!!!

I have zero experience in cooking and I made sushi following these clear instructions. To my surprise, my kids loved these experimental sushi and asked for more.
In my opinion, here is one problem with this recipe.
The amount of rice and water is wrong - it should be doubled.
Although, the proportion of rice to water is correct.
1/4 cup rice should be for 1 roll. 1 cup for 4 rolls.
excellent!
This is so good but you have to use the right knife and I use 1/4 cups of mayonnaise with 3 batches
The exact taste of a sushi restaurant is there. Very difficult to roll without a bamboo roller, so the form wasn't quite right.
Not bad. Won’t use mayo next time. And I’d use 1 thick cucumber strip rather than a few thin.
I would have given it a 5 but it was my first time and I'm sure I can do better.
It was okay. I put too much mayo in it and used the wrong kind of crab meat.
Pretty good! I feel like the measurements are off, because with 1 cup of rice, I was only able to make 4 sushi rolls, not 8, as the instructions said. Apart from that, it's amazing!
Fantastic dish, I like it very much) it has so soft taste) Ideal for me) and really
This was spectacular! I also made it with tune instead of crab. The original version was better

Made this for dinner tonight. Was pretty good with a few modifications. I'm not a huge fan of the raw seaweed so I substituted a mixture of flower eggs milk and butter blended together for the seaweed and rice. Couldn't find my soy sauce but luckily I had some tomato paste that believe it or not was a great stand in. The crab wasn't really my style so I used some ham and ice always loved fruit so I used some pine apple. 

Now I was feeling a little creative so I added some cheese over the whole thing and instead of rolling it just left it flat. Normally I would be totally fine eating it raw but last week I got food poisening so I decided to cook it. I know the traditional method is to fry it but I baked it for my health. 

5 stars. Best sushi ever.
Really need a bamboo mat but this was perfect. Just what I was looking for. Good instructions.
I used real crab instead of fake and it still turned out really good!

I think this is decent sushi for the simplicity of the recipe. I did alter the fat content by replacing the 1/4 cup of mayo for 2 TBSP of light mayo...big difference if you are trying to lose weight! :) Also, if you don't have a bamboo mat like me you can use a clean heavy towel that is folded into a square with some plastic wrap to roll it up (there are videos on youtube and articles on how to do this). Overall good recipe! I'm going to try it next time with cream cheeese. :)
I loved it my dear!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
add salt, less vinegar / then it is awesome
We found that 1/4 c rice vinegar was too much. We followed the sushi rice directions using 2 tbs instead. Very easy and tasted fantastic!
We found that 1/4 c rice vinegar was too much. We followed the sushi rice directions using 2 tbs instead. Very easy and tasted fantastic!

Rice: Add a teaspoon of salt and drop the vinegar to 2 tablespoons and the sugar to 0.5 tablespoons. The keeps the sweet/sour balance the same but gives the rice a more delicate flavor which is supported by the salt.

Crab: Unless you really like mayo use just enough mayo to make the crab hold together. 1-1.5 tablespoons.
Great Recipe.
Pretty good, but definitely too much mayo. A good, classic California roll, super refreshing and filling.
Easy and delicious. Great for first time making sushi.

This recipe was easier than I expected, but requires changes for it to work (at least for me). As prepared, this recipe only made 4 rolls, and the rice was spread too thinly even then. The rice seasoning also had way too much vinegar for my liking.

So here's what I recommend for a recipe that makes 6 rolls using 

2 cups rice (this requires spreading the rice quite thinly, so take your time)

Rice flavoring (goes into the rice after it's cooked, as described in the recipe):
1/4 cup (4 tbsp) rice vinegar
1/4 cup (4 tbsp) water
2 tbsp white sugar
1 tsp salt

Filling:
- 3/8 cup (6 tbsp) imitation crab meat
- 2 small avocados
- 1 small cucumber
- Mayonnaise is optional. I left it out and the rolls tasted very good nonetheless.

Once the rice is ready (cooked, combined with the vinegar mixture, and cooled), split it into 6 equal portions and spread each portion as evenly as you can onto the nori. Split the filling into 6 equal portions as well, prior to adding individual portions to each roll.

Otherwise, follow the original recipe.

And don't forget to get some Japanese soy sauce, fresh or pickled ginger, and wasabi or horseradish if you like to have something salty and spicy to dip your rolls into!
We gobbled this up before I could even finish rolling them. They may not be fancy but they are quite delicious.

Just like the "real thing"! I made the first batch inside out (nori on the outside) because I forgot to flip them, but honestly, it tastes the same regardless, and it's much easier to make them inside out, so that's how I'll make them from now on. I also shaved the cukes with a veggie peeler, which gave me thin, long strands. It's faster and easier than cutting those tiny spears, and all you need to do is put a few strips on each roll; the length is just right. And finally, I used the recipe on the package of sushi rice, which has different concentrations of vinegar/sugar and also uses salt. I'll be making this often!
For the rice i put a couple teaspoon of salt and instead of mayo i used cream cheese, tasted amazing

My kids and I enjoyed this but for some reason the flavoring of the rice bothered me a little. I think it's because I could taste the rice over everything else. Otherwise a good, simple and enjoyable treat.

Thank you for the easy to follow instructions. My CA rolls look very pretty. After learning how to make this, I don't think I would want to buy CA rolls from restaurants anymore. The ingredients are so simple and easy to prepare. Most of the time is spent cooking the rice and cutting.

I agree with a previous review, this is a great recipe for the beginner cook. I also took the advice of others & added salt to the vinegar. I also used real crab meat with a dash of sesame oil and chopped water chestnuts to give crunch, I added mayo to taste. Cooking is about creativity and doing what u like & enjoying what u create. Release the inner chef and go with it. Thank you for those who have shared!

This was my very first time making sushi and I felt that they came out pretty well. I found that there was not nearly enough rice for the amount of nori sheets stated in the recipe (maybe I laid it on a little too heavy). I ended up making only half (4 rolls). I also found that the crameat filling amount was not adequate. I used whipped cream cheese & a little mayo for the surimi mixture & added some hot sauce to spice it up. All and all, a fair effort with decent results. The recipe was easy to follow and I'm sure I'll become more adept with practice.
love the taste it's great!!!!!

These were really good and very filling. I cut my recipe down to only make 2 servings since I would be the only one eating them. Did taste like too much mayo. I even added a bit more crab to mine bc I could see the mayo was overpowering. I've never rolled sushi before so my rolls were kinda thick but that didn't mess with the overall taste. I will make these again!

I HAVE MADE THIS ABOUT 3 OR 4 TIMES NOW AND IT'S GREAT,THE ONLY THING I DID DIFFERENT WAS INSTEAD OF PLAIN RICE VINEGAR I USED SEASONED RICE VINEGAR(B/C THAT'S ALL I HAD) AND I AM GLAD I DID, IT WAS A HIT WITH MY HUSBAND WHO HAS TRIED MINE WHEN I ORDER IT WHEN WE GO OUT AND DOESN'T USUALLY LIKE SUSHI,NOW HE HAS COME HOME TWICE IN ONE WEEK ASKING ME TO MAKE MORE!
delish, if you have not tried this recipe......try it.

Good base recipe for people who want to try making sushi for the first time. Although, the rice is better with Mirin instead of sugar in my opinion, and no mayonnaise, to me it just doesn't belong. And instead of two slices of avocado I would add a slice of folded egg omelette, shitake mushroom, or cucumber. overall good recipe though. And it's nice to finally see someone mentioning the way the rice should be prepared, rinsing and all!
this is a good basic sushi recipe, we didnt make the exact recipe yet

This is a very good basic recipe. I make my sushi a little bit differently, though. First, I do not use any mayo with my crab - I like the flavour on its own. Also, I like to lay slices of cucumber alongside the crab and avacado - makes for a bit of a crunch. Yum!
Sushi doesn't have mayonnaise. You could also substitute another vegetable instead of avocado and only use one; two is a bit much.
This is the best kind of sushi for a begginer sushi chef to practice on. I didn't add any mayo (don't care for it). Thank You!
Excellent combination. I didn't have enough rice, though. Next time I'm going to double the rice so I don't run out.

Very tasty. I cut down on the amount of mayo (about 2-3 TBSP) and also cut the rice vinegar down by 1/3. I didn't flip it, as suggested, just rolled it normally. The ride wash seemed to help with the bag rice I used. I will make this again!

I also added 1 tsp of salt to the vinegar. Fish roe adds not only flavor but color. Just used enough mayo to hold the crabmeat together so it won´t overpower the other ingredients. Removed the seeds from the cucumber and be generous with the sesame seeds.

The first time I make these, they came out rather large but everyone loved them. I took the recommendation and used less mayo. Then I added alittle siracha hot sauce to the mayo to make them Spicy California rolls. Very tasty!!!!!!!
Way too much mayonnaise ratio to finely chopped crabmeat. It drowned out the crabmeat taste. Instead of 1/4 cup mayo, I'd put 1-1.5 tbsp for 1/2 a cup of crabmeat.

not bad, but traditional sushi rice should have a bit of salt in it. the correct method is to add about 1 tsp salt per three cups of rice, you dissolve the salt with the sugar in the vinegar, so for one cup rice, it would be about 1/3 tsp salt. otherwise, this would be perfect.
It was excellent, turned out perfect.
